These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBrought to you byNEWSQUEST COMMERCIAL CONTENTSponsoredSupport and advice on coping with grief and bereavement during covid-Here are businesses that will offer nothing but assistance, advice and quality of care of the highest order.Green Willow FuneralsGreen Willow Funerals Ltd is pleased to introduce and host Grief Chat as a support feature on on our website.Grief Chat was founded in  in response to the long waiting times experienced by many bereaved people who are trying to find support for themselves or for their bereaved family members or friends.Most people expect to be very upset or distressed when someone close to them has died. What takes many people by surprise is how strong the emotions can be, how they can change very quickly, and how long they last. People around you may seem to think you should be lsquoback to normalrsquo after a few weeks or months. You might appear to be your usual self to other people, but you know that on the inside, you are not even sure what normal is anymore.Everyone grieves in a way that is unique to them and their relationship with the person who has died. Well-intentioned people may say to you, lsquotime is a great healerrsquo. Sometimes, however, it can seem that le is more dficult as the weeks and months go by.We know that no one can understand exactly what your loss feels like to you. But we do understand that it is sometimes easier to talk to someone outside of your friends and family about grief and the impact of bereavement of your le and this is why we offer the GriefChat service.GriefChat was created by bereavement experts and by clicking on the GriefChat box below, you can chat directly to a specially trained bereavement counsellor. GriefChat counsellors are experienced in supporting bereaved people and will listen to your story, explore how your grief is affecting you and help you to find any additional support you might need. GriefChat is a completely free service and is available Monday-Friday, am-pm or by email out of these hours.GriefChat provides emotional support for bereaved people, access to trained bereavement counsellors and referral into other specialist bereavement services.Penarth Funeral DirectorsPenarth Funeral Directors aim is to provide professional care services during a time of need offering advice and support to bereaved families when they need it the most.It is our policy not to impose urgency or to apply any undue pressure on you or your family. Funerals are personal and inidual and therefore must reflect your ideas and needs.It is very important to us that you are satisfied with every detail, so please let us know how we can make the day as special as possible to bring you comfort when remembering your loved one. Our courteous and respectful staff are here to guide and assist you throughout.Park Funeral DirectorsPark Funerals are independent family-owned funeral directors, who are well-established and have been serving the local community for many years.During this time, we have built a wonderful reputation based on our commitment to delivering exceptional standards. title: year old penarth man made town drum bass capital
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityZak King was  when he realised he wasnrsquot going to make it as a musician, but after spending much of his childhood and teenage years growing his passion for drum and bass, he knew he needed to do whatever he could to get into the industry.The former Ysgol Gymraeg Pen-y-Garth student started his own record label that year, called Incurzion Audio, and hersquos since gone from strength to strength.With  drum and bass musicians across the UK now on board, the company became the first ever Welsh record label to make Drum and Bass Arenarsquos top  Newcomer Category in , and Mr King repeated the feat in .Explaining why he is sure Penarth is the capital of drum and bass in Wales, and possibly the UK, he said: ldquoWe believe at this stage we can say we are the biggest drum and bass record label to come out of Wales. It is judged on those awards and the quality of your signings, and wersquore proud wersquove managed to gain that title.ldquoPenarth is also home to drum and bass clothing brand Concrete Junglists which has become known worldwide, and High Contrast ndash who is a drum and bass icon ndash was born here.Talking more about how he got into the industry, Mr King said: ldquoI always wanted to be involved in the industry and realised by  I wasnrsquot going to make it as a musician.ldquoIt just wasnrsquot coming together and didnrsquot feel like it was me.ldquoItrsquos something Irsquom really passionate about but it started off as quite a light-hearted thing just giving away free music.ldquoThen it started to grow slowly and some people started to approach us, and then in  it just boomed with the top  acclaim. We started getting lots more people approach us, and wersquore now in a great position. Itrsquos been surprising.A host of top DJs including Miaszmafrom Florida, and Austrian duo Divisionand Seculahave signed up to the label, and Incurzion has grown exponentially in Florida, Austria, Germany and Russia.But strangely, Mr King says, he doesnrsquot think the label is known about by many people in Penarth.ldquoI feel wersquore starting to get rewards now for the way wersquove tried to really stand out in what is a saturated market, he said. ldquoWe feel wersquove done that by trying to offer a dferent sound and brand.ldquoOur style is deep and dark drum and bass, dark branding and graphic design ndash almost like horror.ldquoBut most of all itrsquos about bringing on board top quality musicians, and thatrsquos what wersquove managed to do.ldquoItrsquos been a massive shock to see how much interest our music is getting from Florida since Miaszma signed. Itrsquos really exciting.ldquoI donrsquot think people living in Penarth really know about this townrsquos standing in the drum and bass industry. Itrsquos quite unbelievable for a small town to have such a big connection, and I think it needs to be celebrated more.As lockdown hit last March, so did all of Incurzionrsquos events, which kept Mr King busy every week.He believes musicians have been ignored throughout the pandemic, which he worries may have caused a mental health crisis in the industry.ldquoAs live events go wersquove been absolutely decimated, he said. ldquoThe financial impact of that on venues and on companies like ours, as well as inidual musicians, has been unbelievable.ldquoBut fortunately for us our digital sales have been through the roof. That might be because people have more time on their hands at home to explore dferent genres, and itrsquos great they feel they want to purchase our music.ldquoBut the major thing for this industry is the live events, wersquore nothing without those, just like every other label and performer.ldquoThe funding has been awful, and the impact this will have on mental health seems largely ignored.ldquoThis is what we do every single week, and to have that stripped away from you for so long is dficult. Itrsquos also our place to network, so to not have that space will have long-term ramications.ldquoI know venues in Cardf that have had next to no support, andit carries on you canrsquot see how theyrsquod survive.With cases going down by the week, he hopes the music industry will be able to start up just in time for those venues and for musicians.ldquoWersquore obviously very eager to get back to le as it was, and to pick up where we left off.To find out more about Penarthrsquos Incurzion Audio, visit https:www.incurzionaudio Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cardiff vale launch eating disorder support website
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityTo mark Eating Disorder Awareness Week, Cardf and Vale Adult Eating Disorders Service has launched a new website to support people living with eating disorders.Created in close collaboration with service users, artists, film-makers, counsellors, psychologists, a dietitian and web designer Rhys Welsh, the new website highlights pathways people can follow to find support.Around . million people in the UK currently live with an eating disorder. Anorexia, bulimia and other eating disorders are challenging at the best of times.During the COVID- pandemic, additional stresses have included not being able to see family and friends, outdoor exercise being limited to once a day, and the potential binge-purge cycle arising from stockpiling food due to being required to shop as infrequently as possible.An eating disorder is a mental illness that manests as an unhealthy attitude to food, which can become obsessive and make you unwell.People with eating disorders might eat too much or too little, spend a lot of time worrying about body shape and weight, and have very strict routines around food and exercise. Eating disorders can affect anyone of any age, gender, ethnicity or background.Evenyour symptoms donrsquot directly match those of anorexia, bulimia or binge eating, you may still have an eating disorder. The important thing is to get help.Example of artwork that forms part of the new eating disorder websiteJo Whitfield, National Officer, Wales, at BEAT, said: ldquoThe new Cardf and Vale adult eating disorder service website is a friendly and welcoming gateway for people affected by eating disorders."Itrsquos a place where those who are contemplating seeking help for an eating disorder can find out more about the recovery journey they are about to embark on, and it provides those already undergoing treatment an inspiring place toto throughout their journey.MORE NEWS:"The content is a wonderful collaboration drawing upon lived experience from past and present users of the service. It interweaves art, photography, poetry and animation with factual advice and guidance in one accessible virtual hub, bringing reassurance, hope and belief that recovery from these serious mental illnesses is achievable and possible."The project is fantastic and I look forward to seeing the collection of art and poetry continue to grow as people continue with their journeys to recovery.The website launch is being celebrated with the opening of The Creative Insights exhibition, featuring artwork commissioned by Cardf and Vale Health Charity.Example of artwork that forms part of the new eating disorder websiteYou can view The Creative Insights exhibition via The Virtual Hearth Gallery. The healing benefits of creativity and art are central to the concept of the new website.The creation of the website provides an opportunity for service users to meet online weekly and work alongside facilitators Katja Stiller and Sarah Featherstone to relax with mindfulness, find their creative flow in writing and drawing, sharing their experiences and positive coping mechanisms.ldquoThe group formed a special bond, supporting each other through lockdown," said Debbie Woodward, Consultant Clinical Psychologist, Cardf and Vale University Health Board."Participants reported that they were grateful to have something positive to focus on in a safe space, and to give something back."One service user said the overall experience "has been truly remarkable" for them, and deem themselves lucky to have had the opportunity to take part.The website features specially created animations to help people to better understand eating disorders. The website is a collaboration between the Cardf and Vale University Health Board Psychology directorate, Dietetics, Cardf  Vale Health Charity and Tanio. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: no evidence suggest mahamud mohamed hassan tasered

Just hours later, he died suddenly.The Independent Office for Police Conducthas been investigating the incident, and has released an update, saying it is making "good progress".IOPC director for Wales, Catrin Evans, said: ldquoWe are aware that there is a lot of speculation about the circumstances surrounding Mr Hassanrsquos death and we now know that some of that is inaccurate."As a public body we have a duty, when we are able, to try to correct misinformation that may be in the public domain.The IOPC has said investigators have listened to the original emergency call from the evening of January , in which a caller claimedfive men had entered the Newport Road address and were fighting with the five occupants within the property.It said officersrsquo body worn video footage shows that on arrival a number of the occupants had injuries, and were questioned by officers at the scene about where the injuries came from.The IOPC has said it has found no evidence to suggest Mr Hassan was Tasered at any stage before or during his arrest. This followed a search of the flat, reviewing footage, officer accounts, pathology information and an audit trail of Taser use within the South Wales Police force area.The investigation continues, with IOPC still gathering accounts from "a large number" of police officers and staff who were on duty at Cardf Bay police station over two separate shts and those who were in supervisory positions.IOPC is obtaining detailed accounts from:  officers who attended the Newport Road address on January . officers who attended the Newport Road address the following evening when Mr Hassan died. officers and detention officers who were on duty over two shts at the custody suite.Plus, IOPC is gathering accounts from  officers who have been identied from events linked to the Newport Road address around that time which do not include the arrest or sudden death of Mr Hassan.Ms Evans added: ldquoThere is much more work to do to complete our investigation and our investigators continue to gather and review evidence to help us establish the events leading up to Mr Hassanrsquos death."We need to ensure we have spoken to anyone who may possibly have useful information to help us build a picture of what happened.ldquoWe have concentrated on the footage from police body worn video and from CCTV at the custody suite which covers the time Mr Hassan spent there and his release from the police station."As our review of this material nears completion, we intend to move on to scrutinise street and private footage which has been secured, which we hope will assist in identying Mr Hassanrsquos movements following his release from custody, and may open up further lines of enquiry.ldquoAn investigation like this does take time and we would ask people to be patient while the title: cardiff vale health board propose changes services
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityLike other regions around the UK, the Health Board faces a number of challenges, including meeting the needs of a growing and ageing population, staff shortages and outdated hospital facilities.Cardf and Vale UHB provides healthcare services and specialist services to people in Cardf and the Vale, South Wales, the whole of Wales and the wider UK.The Health Board is also a major teaching and research organisation. As one of the largest and most complex healthcare systems in the UK, it faces unique challenges in the way it develops its services, staff and ambitions for the future.Len Richards, CEO of Cardf and Vale UHB, said ldquoOur vision as a Health Board is simple a personrsquos chance of leading a healthy le should be the same no matter who they are or where they live."This is a key part of our -year Shaping Our Future Wellbeing strategy. Building on this, we would like to make a number of transformations to the way people access our clinical services, with a focus on providing more care closer to home wherever possible."Our Shaping Our Future Clinical Services programme aims to inform our communities of our thinking and seek feedback to inform our direction of travel.As part of the Shaping Our Future Clinical Services programme, the Health Board is proposing a number of changes to the way people access clinical services, including:Bringing care closer to its communities and continuing to develop Health and Wellbeing Centres and Wellbeing Hubs - as well as enhancing its model for care at home.The Health Board would like to develop Health and Wellbeing Centres in each of its three localities at Cardf Royal Infirmary, Barry and North Cardf.These will provide the infrastructure to support services that cannot be delivered through Wellbeing Hubs due to dependence on equipment, facilities or critical mass.Cardf and Vale UHB would also like to establish Wellbeing Hubs in each of its nine Primary Care Clusters, delivering services for GPs, community midwery, for children, primary mental health, community and independent living.Other proposed changes include more care happening at home or closer to home in community settings.University Hospital LlandoughUniversity Hospital of Walescould be enhanced as a centre for emergency and specialised care, focused on research and innovation, providing care for the sickest patients who have complex, specialist needs or require emergency care.The Health Board envisages University Hospital Llandoughspecialising in care for ill but stable patients who are not dependent on critical care during their stay.MORE NEWS:Routine and planned operations would take place at this site, as well as rehabilitation care and inpatient mental health services. State-of-the-art facilities would continue to be developed at UHL and a renewed UHW established.The proposed transformations to clinical services would have a number of benefits to both staff and the population. These could include:High-quality, safe and sustainable care for the future with improved outcomesAccessible care provided closer to home wherever possibleEnhanced specialist servicesState-of-the-art facilities in modern buildingsStreamlined services with shorter stays in hospital.From st March to th April , Cardf and Vale UHB is inviting members of the public to learn more about the proposed transformations and provide feedback.In partnership with the South Glamorgan Community Health Council , the Health Board will also be running a series of open public engagement events. title: dyffryn gardens joins cerys matthews backing plant health campaign
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe physical and mental health benefits of planting and growing are well understood, and as spring approaches our thoughts turn to our precious gardens, as people across Wales make their planting plans and purchases for the growing season ahead.Plant enthusiast and famous singer, songwriter, author and broadcaster Cerys Matthews is backing a Welsh Government campaign to offer advice and guidance to enhance our enjoyment of the garden, by sourcing plants carefully, inspecting them on arrival to detect and control the spread of pests and diseases, and adopting good husbandry practices.Cerys is passionate about the countryside, and created the Good Le Experience festival of culture and the great outdoors in North Wales.Cerys Matthews She said: ldquoI adore plants, I talk to them and play music to them. They are just so vitally important, providing the oxygen we breathe and the food we eat, and bring le to our iconic countryside."We need to look after plants and keep them healthy and free of plant pests and diseases.With garden centres in Wales currently closed and buyers sourcing online, the campaignrsquos key plant biosecurity messages are:Buy plants from knowledgeable suppliers who you can ask where the plant was sourced from, how to care for it, and what plant pests and diseases it might be prone to.Seek advice from Walesrsquo excellent network of independent, knowledgeable garden centres and retailers.Regularly clean your garden tools and footwear to stop the spread of invasive plants, plant pests or plant diseases.Dispose of unwanted plants and plant material responsibly. Not all plants are suitable for composting. Do not allow invasive plants, plant pests or plant diseases to spread from your land.There are a number of ways you can control plant pests, weeds and diseases. Always consider non-chemical control before using chemical pesticides.If you do decide to use pesticides, always read the product label carefully before use. This may specy or recommend specic actions for use. Always dispose of unused pesticides and pesticide containers responsibly.MORE NEWS:This Plant Health campaign is being supported by  Plant Health Sentinel Sites across Wales.These are parks and gardens, such as the National Botanic Garden, Bodnant Garden, and Dyffryn Gardens, that are working with our Animal and Plant Health inspectors to act as an early warning system for plant pests and diseases, and promoting good plant health practice to the wider public for the benefit of our wildle, the environment, our culture, well-being and economy.Dyffryn Gardens The network took part this week in a virtual event, which was addressed by Welsh Minister for Environment, Energy and Rural Affairs, Lesley Grfiths MS, a keen gardener herself.The Minister said: ldquoProtecting plants safeguards le, creating the air we breathe and most of the food we eat. We appreciate now, more than ever before, how important our plants, gardens and parks are to our le and wellbeing, and this campaign will promote best practice and help people grow healthy plants.The campaign is also backed by famous Welsh landscape designers the Rich brothers, Gold Medal winners at the RHS Cha Flower Show TV gardening presenter Meinir Gwilym and Medwyn Williams,  times Cha Gold winner for his outstanding vegetables.Further information on non-chemical control may be found on the RHS website https:www.rhs.org.uk advice profile pid.The campaign is also working with Tyfu Cymru, funded by Welsh Government to build the capacity and capability of the Welsh horticulture industry, who are spreading the biosecurity message amongst the commercial sector, raising awareness of the real threats of plant pests and diseases like Xyllela, a destructive plant pathogen best known for its effect on Italian olive trees. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAsteroid  Apophis will fly past Earth this Fridaygiving astronomers an opportunity to study the body ahead of the asteroids closer approach in .During its  pass Apophis - which is pronounced uh-pow-fuhs and measures  metres across - will comfortably skirt our planet at a safe distance of ,, miles.However, in April  Apophis will literally shave Earth at a distance of just , miles - it will be visible to the naked-eye as it passes among the zone where high altitude satellites are present.As with a number of other asteroids, Apophis has been classied as a potentially hazardous asteroidby the International Astronomical Unionrsquos Minor Planet Center.This means that Apophisis an asteroid whose orbit brings it occasionally near to Earth, and is large enough to cause ldquosignicant regional damage in the event of an impact.Discovered on June by American astronomers Roy A. Tucker and David J. Tholen, along with Italian astronomer Fabrizio Bernardi, the asteroid is comfortably larger than the Efel Tower and its April  passage will be the closest asteroid of its size in recorded history to pass Earth.With further passes to follow the asteroids April odds of striking the Earth are one in ,.While Apophis is not an imminent threat to Earth scientists are running a simulated planetary defence scenario pretending that they just spotted it in the sky in December, to prepare for a possible situation in the future. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. and will be opening another Cardf-based one towards the end of March.They are working in partnership with Cardf Council and Vale of Glamorgan Council to increase capacity for vaccinations and the new Bayside MVC will enable additional capacity of up to , vaccines per day, which will be dependent on vaccine supply.The new centre is being developed on the former Toys R Us site at the International Sports Village - this site will be accessible for residents in Eastern Vale and people in Cardf.Along with the mass vaccination centres, all  GP practices across the two counties are taking part in the vaccination programme, with community pharmacies set to join the programme from April.Executive Director of Public Health at Cardf and Vale University Health Board, Fiona Kinghorn, said: ldquoThis is the largest vaccination programme the NHS has even been involved in and to date tremendous progress has been made."So far we have vaccinated over a third of our adult population with first doses and some are now receiving their second doses which provides the best protection.ldquoWe are working closely with all of our partners and stakeholders to enable us to deliver the vaccine to as many people as possible as quickly as possible and have been grateful to those that have supported us through this process."Over the next few weeks we anticipate our capacity to increase in line with the new centre and support of our primary care contractors.OTHER NEWS:Volunteers helping deliver injection of hope are praised for their effortsMeet the retired haematologist and the RAF nurse helping the vaccination effortVale Cabinet Member for Health and Social Care, Cllr Ben Gray, said: "More than , vaccinations have now been given in Cardf and the Vale and the collective effort to reach this number has been nothing short of phenomenal."The Vale of Glamorgan Council has worked closely with our partners in the health board and Cardf Council to ensure we are able to administer all available vaccine as quickly as possible."This new centre for Cardf and the Vale will allow us to move through the next priority groups even more quickly and bring the end of the pandemic closer still."In addition to the new centre, the health board is also scoping out opportunities to increase local access in the Western Vale of Glamorgan. Discussions are taking place with GP practices in the area and community pharmacies to provide additional vaccination capacity to residents living in this area.To date the Health Board has delivered more than , vaccines with , of these being first doses.Priority Groups - are currently being contacted for their first doses while groups - will start to be contacted for their second doses over the coming months. Mission Control called it quits at that point and told the astronauts to skip extra chores.A Nasa spokesman at Johnson Space Centre in Houston, Rob Navias, said Ms Rubinsrsquo suit pressure held perfectly throughout the spacewalk.ldquoAt no time was she in any danger, he said in an email.Teamwork, but make it space-y. # pic cmtaFdHSmdash NASAMarch , Nasa is enhancing the space stationrsquos power grid to accommodate more astronauts and experiments, now that SpaceX is launching crews and Boeing should be too by yearrsquos end.The eight solar  have degraded over time the oldest were launched  years ago.The six new solar wings mdash smaller but more efficient mdash will fit over the older ones and boost the stationrsquos power capability by up to %.Boeing is supplying the , which will be launched in pairs by SpaceX over the next year.On Sunday, a number of stubborn bolts prevented Ms Rubins and Nasa astronaut Victor Glover from completing the support setup.As the spacewalk ended, Mission Control congratulated Mr Noguchi for having the longest gap between spacewalks: fteen-and-a-half years.His previous three spacewalks occurred in , during the first shuttle flight following the  Columbia disaster.This should be the last spacewalk for the stationrsquos current residents, whose half-year missions are coming to a close.Ms Rubins willto Earth in mid-April in a Russian capsule, along with two Russians. inidual who tested positive for the iant of concern, with the team narrowing in on them among thousands of potential households.Three cases of the P iant, first identied in the Brazilian city of Manaus, were detected in England on February .A public appeal was launched for one of those people to come forward after they left no contact details.Speaking at a Downing Street press conference on Friday, Public Health Englandrsquos Dr Susan Hopkins detailed how they were successfully found.She explained that the unnamed person, who lives in Croydon, south London, had attempted to register his test online, but ldquohad failed to do so effectively.Dr Hopkins continued: ldquoSpecialist teams from NHS Test and Trace and Public Health England immediately launched an investigation to identy the inidual concerned.ldquoAn incident team of  people from across the system made up of laboratories, logistics, data analytic experts was mobilised to trace the inidual.ldquoThe team began with very little information.She said, on Sunday morning, they were only in possession of a single barcode and the date and time that the test was processed at the Cambridge Lighthouse laboratory. vw,vw,px, px"Healthcare Epidemiologist Consultant Susan Hopkins The discovery, via reading the test barcode, that the sample had arrived at the Cambridge Lighthouse through the DHL service for home delivery helped narrow it down to two regions made up of , possible households.Even though NHS Test and Trace delivers ldquomany thousands of kits a week, the team were able to compare the test in question to others in the system and work ldquobackwards from when it arrived in the laboratory, to which testing hub it had come from and through the postal service.Their intelligence was then ldquooverlaid with the geographical spread to look for the correlation of sequential barcodes, Dr Hopkins said.Once the region and ldquotime window for the test were combined, experts tracked down ldquoevery single distribution centre to filter down options.These were narrowed to  households with ldquoenhanced contact tracing then kicking-in, with call handlers phoning and emailing those who could have received a test in that time interval.This scaled it down to  iniduals who received further calls and text messages.Dr Hopkins said: ldquoOn Wednesday at pm, an inidual phoned the  service.ldquoThey were able to give the missing barcode number that they had held securely for the whole time.ldquoThis inidual has been interviewed extensively and lives within a household that had recently ed from Brazil and all had quarantined at home.ldquoFurther precautionary testing will occur in the neighbourhood and we have already started testing all of the samples from the neighbourhood through whole genome sequencing to ensure there is no further distribution of cases in the community.She added: ldquoThis is a testament to the NHS Test and Trace teams, the call handlers and the Public Health England health protection team working together to find an inidual and prevent further transmission.Health secretary Matt Hancock also hailed the ldquobrilliant team who had been ldquoworking so hard over the past week.He said: ldquoUsing the latest technology and with the dogged determination of our Testing and Tracing scheme, we have successfully identied the person in question.ldquoThe best evidence is that this person in question stayed at home and there is no sign that therersquos been any onward transmission but as a precaution we are putting more testing in in Croydon where they live to minimise As our forests develop as places of industry, environment and leisure, we are encouraging everyone to make their views known.“County Armagh boasts some of Northern Ireland’s best known, and most popular, forests such as Gosford and Slieve Gullion forests. Both of these forest parks have had considerable investments in recent years by the local Councils in partnership with Forest Service, to improve and develop paths, trails and playparks.”Forests in County Armagh are also working forests that produce timber for the Northern Ireland wood processing industry. From County Armagh each year Forest Service supplies around , lorry loads of timber every year. Forest Service has also planted around , trees in the county in the last five years.The Minister continued: “Reviewing forest plans ensures that they are up to date and allows us to continue to meet the erse and sometimes competing needs of people, wildle and wood processing industries. We want to hear from all stakeholders to ensure that all interests are considered, including from those who live and work in local rural communities.”The consultation opened on  March and ends on  April . story: Ryanair has announced it willto Belfast City Airport after  years and is delighted to launch  new routes for summer ’ connecting Belfast to a host of popular international summer destinations. Ryanair’s Director of Marketing, Dara Brady said: “We are delighted to make ato Belfast City Airport this summer, having previously operated here in .
